awd_titl_txt: Combustion characteristics of pulverized torrefied biomass for use in co-firing boilers
awd_abstract_narration:
To satisfy energy needs of the fast-growing global population and minimize the negative impact on the environment, alternative energy sources are needed. The U.S. has a large capacity for renewable biomass production, the utilization of which can reduce the total carbon emissions. Partial substitution of coal with biomass can be a viable option for generating the baseload power that most alternative sources (wind, solar, tidal) cannot supply due to their intermittent nature. However, biomass is moist, biodegradable and fibrous. Thus, it is costly to transport, store and grind for use in the boilers. This research will address the combustion of torrefied biomass, which has been subjected to the process of torrefaction (akin to coffee roasting) to remove moisture, chlorine and sulfur. However, as grinding costs drastically increase with decreasing targeted grind size, this work aims to identify appropriate maximum torrefied biomass particle size ranges for effective combustion in existing boilers. Such knowledge is needed for torrefied biomass to become a standardized product for burning in virtually unmodified coal-fired plants. During the course of this research, students will be educated in the energy field and several international collaborations will be advanced on the subject of harvesting bioenergy to help achieve a sustainable environment.

This research will generate new knowledge pertinent to effective combustion of torrefied biomass in utility boilers. This investigation will identify methods for assessing the proper size of various kinds of torrefied biomass materials (including several typical woody and herbaceous biomass types) for co-firing with pulverized coal, while maintaining high combustion efficiencies and high radiative fluxes in existing boilers. Data pertinent to particle burnout times, temperatures of both volatile matter flames and residual chars, in-flame soot volume fractions, particle-to-particle interactions, carbon burnout are needed to predict reaction rates, heat fluxes, and slagging and fouling deposition tendencies in boilers. The proposed fundamental research will assess these combustion parameters of pulverized torrefied biomass at the particle level, by monitoring entire combustion histories of single particles pyrometrically and cinematographically. These will be compared to analogous data for coal particles of all ranks, previously collected in this laboratory. Subsequently, combustion effectiveness and particle-to-particle interactions will be assessed by burning streams of neat and blended fuels and emissions will be monitored.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental investigation, including recommendations for practical applications, was conducted on the combustion characteristics of pulverized torrefied biomass particles at high heating rates (10,000 K/s) and high temperatures (Tgas=1350 K), in both in air and in simulated oxy-combustion gases, composed of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Such conditions are relevant to those prevailing in utility pulverized coal suspension boilers. Comparisons of the combustion characteristics of biomass and coal were made, in case the former fuel is burned in coal-fired boilers alone or blended with coal.

Biomass was burned both under conventional air-fired combustion conditions and under oxy-combustion conditions. Power generation by oxy-combustion of renewable biomass, coupled with carbon-dioxide capture and utilization or sequestration (CCU/CCS), can contribute to a reduction of the atmospheric concentration of CO2. This is because while renewable biomass absorbs carbon dioxide during its growth, CCU/CCS releases none to the atmosphere. It facilitates carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and sequestration in underground reservoirs, so that it can either be kept therein or be recycled for further usage.

This investigation focused on torrefied biomass (mildly roasted to remove its moisture and thereby reduce its biodegradability, enhance its friability, enhance its fluidization by reducing its particle aspect ratios, etc.), but it also included raw biomass in some tasks. Some of the goals of this investigation are mentioned below.

A goal of this investigation was to explore the maximum targeted particle size of pulverized torrefied biomass that can be burned in existing coal-fired suspension boilers. This would minimize the power consumed to grind biomass chunks to small sizes. Typical coal particle sizes in such boilers are in the range of 75-90 μm. Based on combustion observations, the nominal sieve size of the examined torrefied biomass particles whose observed burnout times matched those of the targeted coal particles was determined to be 212-300 μm. Hence, to minimize the grinding cost of torrefied biomass for combustion in suspension boilers, finer pulverization than this size range may not be necessary. Additional experiments and kinetic modelling revealed that biomass particles injected in hot furnaces, upon experiencing high heating rates undergo melting and spherodization. Upon pyrolysis/devolatilization, their volatile matter burns and the residual chars shrink to small sizes and are highly porous. Chars of typical 75-90 μm bituminous coal particles are a little bigger than their parent particles and have porosities in the neighborhood of 60%. Chars of 212-300 μm torrefied biomass particles are of much smaller size than their parent particles, but have porosities in the neighborhood of 94%. Thus, it is not surprising that the torrefied biomass particles burn as fast as the aforesaid coal particles. Nevertheless, the biomass size determinations in this investigation should be validated in pilot-scale boilers, where large quantities of ash can be collected and the unburned carbon in the ash can be reliably assessed.

Another goal of this investigation was to determine the minimum oxygen mole fraction in the furnace input gases in the case of oxy-combustion, which still allows single particles of biomass to burn in a manner similar to their combustion in air. Oxy-combustion replaces air with mixtures of neat oxygen (supplied from an air separation unit) and recycled CO2 to moderate combustion temperatures. Depending on the biomass type, it was found that the gaseous mixtures that would result in biomass combustion temperature and burnout time parameters most similar to those of air combustion were between 21%O2/79%CO2 and 30%O2/70%CO2, with exact values depending on the biomass type.

Another goal of this investigation was to minimize emissions from combustion of biomass. Particularly, curtailing emissions of chlorine-bearing gases is important because they are corrosive and participate in the formation of water-tube deposits in the boiler. It was documented that burning torrefied biomass instead of raw biomass drastically minimizes such emissions. This is because a most significant fraction of chlorine is released during torrefaction. Conditions for torrefaction that promote release of chlorine to the gas phase were identified, because it was deemed advantageous to release the chlorine in the typically refractory torrefaction furnaces than in the corrosion-prone metal-clad boilers. For instance, in the case of corn-straw, nearly half of its chlorine content was found to be released during torrefaction. While this is desirable for the generation of a better fuel, control of chlorinated gases in the torrefaction furnace is still needed. To achieve this goal, research was conducted where the torrefaction gas (torgas), containing mostly HCl and CH3Cl, was heterogeneously reacted with beds of powdered alkali carbonate sorbents (CaCO3, Na2CO3, K2CO3) at 25, 300, or 500 oC.  The removal of both HCl and CH3Cl by the sorbents increased with increasing bed temperature. The increase was steep when the bed temperature was raised from 25 to 300 oC, whereas it was milder when the temperature was raised from 300 to 500 oC. Therefore, it was deemed economically sensible to choose 300 oC.
